content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.The following questions relate to sulfur and some of its compounds.(a) Write the balanced equation for the combustion of <math alttext="S 8, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to form <math alttext="S O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.The following questions relate to sulfur and some of its compounds.(a) Write the balanced equation for the combustion of <math alttext="S 8, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to form <math alttext="S O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Calculate the volume of <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, measured at <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that is required to completely combust a <math alttext="500.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of pure <math alttext="S 8, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) A student claims that the combustion of <math alttext="S 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is an oxidation-reduction reaction. Justify the claim by identifying the oxidation numbers of sulfur and oxygen both before and after the reaction.

(d) In the box below, draw a Lewis electron-dot diagram for one valid resonance structure of <math alttext="S O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Based on the diagram you drew in part (d), what is the approximate oxygen-sulfur-oxygen bond angle in <math alttext="S O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

<math alttext="S O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> can be oxidized to form <math alttext="S O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> according to the following equation.<math alttext="2 S O 2, gas, plus, O 2, gas, react to produce, 2 S O 3, gas. Delta H naught, equals, negative 198 kilojoules per mole reaction." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>198</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>(f) Is the value of <math alttext="delta S naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction represented above positive or negative? Justify your answer.

<math alttext="2 S O 2, gas, plus, O 2, gas, react to produce, 2 S O 3, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>(g) Is the magnitude of <math alttext="delta H naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction to form <math alttext="S O 3, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, represented above, greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of <math alttext="delta H naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction to form <math alttext="S O 3, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.
(h) Based on the information above, how does the thermodynamic favorability of the reaction change as the temperature of the reaction system is decreased? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
